question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Too  many  times  people,  especially  in  today’s
generation, expect things to just happen  <u>overnight.</u>
When we have these false expectations, it tends to 
<u>discourage  us  from  continuing  to  move  forward.</u>
Because this is a high tech society, everything we want
has to be within the parameters of our comfort and 
<u>confident.</u> If it doesn’t happen fast enough, we’re 
<u>tempted to lose interest.</u> So many people don’t want to
take the time it requires to be successful. Success is
not  a  matter  of  mere  desire;  you  should  develop
patience in order to achieve it. Have you  <u>fallen prey
to impatience?</u> Great things take time to build.
* parameter: 매개 변수, 제한

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
If you had wanted to create a “self- driving” car in the
1950s, your best option might have been to strap a
brick to the accelerator. Yes, the vehicle would have
been able to  move  <u>forward on its own, but it could
not  slow  down,  stop,  or  turn  to  avoid  barriers.</u>
Obviously not  <u>ideal.</u> But does that  mean the entire
concept  of  the  self- driving  car  is  not  worth 
<u>pursuing?</u> No, it only means that at the time we did
not yet have the tools we now possess to help enable
vehicles to operate both autonomously and safely. This
once -distant dream now seems  <u>within our reach.</u> It
is much the same story in medicine. Two decades ago,
we were still taping  bricks to accelerators. Today, we
are approaching the point where we can begin to bring
some appropriate technology to bear in ways that 
<u>impede    our  understanding  of  patients  as  unique
individuals.</u> In fact, many patients are already wearing
devices  that  monitor  their  conditions  in  real  time,
which  allows  doctors  to  talk  to  their  patients  in  a
specific, refined, and feedback -driven way that was not
even possible a decade ago. 
* strap: 끈으로 묶다 ** autonomously: 자율적으로

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
We tend to  <u>overrate the impact of new technologies
in  part  because  older  technologies  have  become
absorbed into the furniture of our lives, so as to be
almost invisible.</u> Take the baby bottle. Here is a simple
implement  that  has  <u>transformed  a  fundamental
human  experience  for  vast  numbers  of  infants  and
mothers,  yet  it  finds  no  place  in  our  histories  of
technology.</u> This technology might be thought of as a
classic  <u>time-shifting  device, as it enables mothers
to exercise more control over the timing of feeding.</u> It
can also function to save time, as bottle feeding allows
for  someone  else  to  <u>substitute  for  the  mother’s
time.</u> Potentially, therefore, it has huge implications for
the  management  of  time  in  everyday  life,  yet  it  is
entirely  <u>overemphasized  in  discussions  of  high-
speed society.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Empathy  is  frequently  listed  as  one  of  the  most 
<u>desired  skills  in  an  employer  or  employee,  although
without specifying exactly what is meant by empathy.</u>
Some   businesses   stress   cognitive   empathy,
emphasizing  the  need  for  leaders  to  understand  the
perspective  of  employees  and  customers  when
negotiating deals and making decisions. Others stress
affective empathy and empathic concern, emphasizing
the ability of leaders to  <u>lose trust from employees
and customers by treating them with real concern and
compassion.</u>   When   some   consultants   argue
that successful companies  <u>foster empathy, what that
translates  to  is  that  companies  should  conduct  good
market  research.</u>  In  other  words,  an  “empathic”
company  understands  the  needs  and  wants  of  its
customers  and  seeks  to  <u>fulfill  those  needs  and
wants.</u>  When  some  people  speak  of  design
with  empathy,  what  that  translates  to  is  that
companies  should  <u>take  into  account  the  specific
needs of different populations — the blind, the deaf,
the elderly, non English speakers, the color blind, and so
on — when designing products.</u>
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장 적

question: 절한 것은?
mainText:
The  most  common  problem  kids  report  is  that  they
feel  like  they  need  to  be (A)  [inaccessible  /
accessible] at  all  times.  Because  technology  allows
for it, they feel an obligation. It’s easy for most of us
to relate : you probably feel the same (B) [pressure
/ relaxation] in your own life! It is really challenging
to  deal  with  the  fact  that  we’re  human  and  can’t
always respond instantly. For a teen or tween who’s
still learning the ins and outs of social interactions, it’s
even  worse.  Here’s  how  this  behavior  plays  out
sometimes: Your child texts one of his friends, and the
friend doesn’t text back right away. Now it’s easy for
your child to think, “This person doesn’t want to be
my friend anymore!” So he texts again, and again, and
again — “blowing up their phone.” This can be stress- -
inducing  and  even  read  as (C)   [passive   /
aggressive]. But you can see how easily this could
happen.
 <u>accessible - pressure - aggressive</u> <u>accessible - pressure - passive</u> <u>accessible - relaxation - passive</u> <u>inaccessible - relaxation - aggressive</u> <u>inaccessible - pressure - aggressive
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장 적</u>

explanation: (A) 첫번째 문장에서 '아이들이 이야기하는 가장 일반 적인 문제는 그들이 항상 [연락할] 수 있어야 한다고 느낀다'는 것 이 문맥의 흐름상 자연스러우므로, (A)는 accessible(접근할 수 있는, 연락 가능한) 이다. (B) 앞선 문장에서 '기술이 우리가 항상 연락할 수 있게 하는 것을 허용하기에, 아이들은 [의무감]을 느낀 다'고 했다. 따라서 글의 흐름상 (B)는 relaxation(안정) 보다는 'pressure'(압박감)이 더 적절하다. (C) 앞의 문장에서 '문자 메세 지를 계속해서 보내다가 전화기를 폭파한다'고 설명하였다. 따라 서 글의 흐름상 '스트레스를 유발하고, 심지어는 [공격적인] 것으 로 읽힐 수 있다'는 것이 더 적절하므로, passive(수동적인)보다 는 'aggressive'(공격적인)이 적절하다.

question: 절한 것은?
mainText:
For  years,  many  psychologists  have  held  strongly  to
the belief that the key to addressing negative health
habits is to change behavior. This, more than values
and attitudes, is the part of personality that is easiest
to change. (A) [Suggestive / Ingestive] habits such
as smoking, drinking and various eating behaviors are
the  most  common  health  concerns  targeted  for
behavioral  changes.  Process- addiction  behaviors
(workaholism,  shopaholism,  and  the  like) (B)  [fall
into  /  fall  to] this category as well. Mental imagery
combined with power of suggestion was taken up as
the  premise  of  behavioral  medicine  to  help  people
change  negative  health  behaviors  into  positive  ones.
Although  this  technique  alone  will  not  produce
changes,  when  used  alongside  other  behavior
modification  tactics  and (C)  [scoping  /  coping]
strategies,  behavioral  changes  have  proved  effective
for  some  people.  What  mental  imagery  does  is
reinforce  a  new  desired  behavior.  Repeated  use  of
images reinforces the desired behavior more strongly
over time.
 <u>Suggestive - fall to - coping</u> <u>Suggestive - fall into - scoping</u> <u>Ingestive - fall to - scoping</u> <u>Suggestive - fall into - coping</u> <u>Ingestive - fall into - coping</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Emotion  socialization  —  learning  from  other  people
about emotions and how to deal with them — starts
early  in  life  and  plays  a  <u>foundational  role  for
emotion  regulation  development.</u>  Although  extra- -
familial  influences,  such  as  peers  or  media,  gain  in
importance  during  adolescence,  parents  remain  the
primary  socialization  agents.  For  example,  their  own
responses  to  emotional  situations  serve  as  a  role
model  for  emotion  regulation,  <u>decreasing  the
likelihood that their children will show similar reactions
in  comparable  situations.</u>  Parental  practices  at  times
when  their  children  are  <u>faced  with  emotional
challenges   also   impact   emotion   regulation
development.</u>  Whereas  direct  soothing  and  directive
guidance  of  what  to  do  are  beneficial  for  younger
children, they may intrude on adolescents’ autonomy
 <u>striving.</u>  In  consequence,  adolescents  might  pull
away from, rather than turn toward, their parents in
times of emotional crisis, unless parental practices are
adjusted. More  <u>suitable in adolescence is indirect
support  of  autonomous  emotion  regulation,  such  as
through  interest  in,  as  well  as  awareness  and
nonjudgmental  acceptance  of,  adolescents’  emotional
experiences, and being available when the adolescent
wants to talk.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Dancers often push themselves to the  <u>limits of their
physical capabilities.</u> But that push is misguided if it is
directed toward accomplishing something physically 
<u>impossible.</u> For instance, a tall dancer with long feet
may wish to perform repetitive vertical jumps to fast
music, pointing his feet while in the air and lowering
his  heels  to  the  floor  between  jumps.  That  may  be
impossible no matter how strong the dancer is. But a
short-footed  dancer  may  have  no  trouble!  Another
dancer may be struggling to complete a half-turn in
the  air.  Understanding  the  <u>connection  between  a
rapid turn rate and the</u> <u>alignmentof the body close
to  the  rotation  axis  tells  her  how  to  accomplish  her
turn   successfully.</u>   In   both   of   these   cases,
understanding  and  working  within  the  constraints
imposed by nature
and described by physical laws allows dancers to work
efficiently, minimizing <u>explicit risk of injury.</u>
text:
Dancers often push themselves to the  <u>limits of their
physical capabilities.</u> But that push is misguided if it is
directed toward accomplishing something physically 
<u>impossible.</u> For instance, a tall dancer with long feet
may wish to perform repetitive vertical jumps to fast
music, pointing his feet while in the air and lowering
his  heels  to  the  floor  between  jumps.  That  may  be
impossible no matter how strong the dancer is. But a
short-footed  dancer  may  have  no  trouble!  Another
dancer may be struggling to complete a half-turn in
the  air.  Understanding  the  <u>connection  between  a
rapid turn rate and the</u> <u>alignmentof the body close
to  the  rotation  axis  tells  her  how  to  accomplish  her
turn   successfully.</u>   In   both   of   these   cases,
understanding  and  working  within  the  constraints
imposed by nature
and described by physical laws allows dancers to work
efficiently, minimizing <u>explicit risk of injury.</u>

① <u>limits of their
physical capabilities.</u>

③ <u>connection  between  a
rapid turn rate and the</u>

to  the  rotation  axis  tells  her  how  to  accomplish  her
turn   successfully.</u>

We  must  explore  the  relationship  between  children’s
film  production  and  consumption  habits.  The  term
“children’s  film”  implies  <u>ownership by  children  —
their cinema — but films supposedly made for children
have always been consumed by audiences of all ages,
particularly in commercial cinemas.</u> The substantial 
<u>crossover in audience composition for children’s films
is evidenced by the following statistics: eleven Danish
children's and  youth films recorded 59% of theatrical
admissions in 2007, and seven German children's films
ranked among the top twenty films at the national box
office  in  2014.</u>  This  phenomenon  fits  into  a  more
widespread, global acceptance of content that appears
to be  <u>targeted at children's audiences, despite their
varied  age  groups.</u>  The  realities  of  consumption 
<u>prove the long-held prejudice that children's film exists
in  a  domain  separate  from (and  forever  subordinate
to)  a  more  legitimate  cinema:  The  significance  of
children's film in today's popular culture cannot be</u>
<u>understated.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Beethoven's  drive  to  create  something  novel  is  a
reflection  of  his  state  of  curiosity.  Our  brains
experience  a  sense  of  reward  when  we  create
something new in the process of exploring something
 <u>uncertain,  such  as  a  musical  phrase  that  we've
never played or heard before.</u> When our curiosity leads
to something novel, the resulting reward brings us a
sense  of  pleasure.  A  number  of  investigators  have
modeled how curiosity makes musical composition 
<u>progressed.</u>  In  the  case  of  Beethoven,  computer
modeling  focused  on  the  thirty two  piano  sonatas
written  after  age  thirteen  revealed  that  the  musical
patterns frequently found in all of Beethoven's music
 <u>decreased  in  later  sonatas.</u>  Conversely,  novel
patterns, including patterns which were  <u>familiar to a
particular  sonata,  increased.</u>  In  other  words,
Beethoven's music became more  <u>unpredictable over
time  as  his  curiosity  drove  the  exploration  of  new
musical ideas.</u> Curiosity is a powerful driver of human
creativity.
* sonata: 악곡의 한 형식

Technologists  are  always  on  the  lookout  for
quantifiable metrics. Measurable inputs to a model are
 <u>critical,  and  like  a  social  scientist,  a  technologist
needs to identify concrete measures, or “proxies,” for
assessing progress.</u> This need for quantifiable proxies
gives rise to a  <u>preference for measuring things that
are  easy  to  quantify.</u>  But  simple  metrics  can   
<u>distance  us from the important goals we really care
about,  which  may  require  complicated  metrics  or  be
extremely difficult, or perhaps impossible, to reduce to
any  measure.</u>  And  when  we  have  imperfect  or  bad
proxies, we can easily fall under the illusion that we
are solving for a good end, yet in reality, we are not
truly  advancing  toward  a  <u>minor solution.</u>  The
problem   of   proxies   results   in   technologists
frequently  <u>substituting what is measurable for what
is meaningful.</u> As the saying goes, “Not everything that
counts can be counted, and not everything that can be
counted counts.”

mainText:
We  are  the  only  species  that  seasons  its  food,
deliberately  altering  it  with  the  highly  flavored  plant
parts we call herbs and spices. It’s quite possible that
our taste for spices has an  <u>evolutionary root.</u> Many
spices have antibacterial properties — in fact, common
seasonings  such  as  garlic,  onion,  and  oregano 
<u>discourage  the  growth  of  almost  every  bacterium
tested.</u> And the cultures that make the heaviest use of
spices — think of the garlic and black pepper of Thai
food,  the  ginger  and  coriander  of  India,  the  chili
peppers  of  Mexico  —  come  from  warmer  climates,
where  bacterial  spoilage  is  a  <u>bigger  issue.</u>  In
contrast, the most  <u>lightly spiced cuisines — those of
Scandinavia  and  northern  Europe  —  are  from  cooler
climates.</u> Our uniquely human attention to  <u>climate,
in  this  case  the  flavor  of  spices,  turns  out  to  have
arisen as a matter of life and death.</u>

Development  of  the  human  body  from  a  single  cell
provides many  <u>examples of the structural richness
that  is  possible  when  the  repeated  production  of
random  variation  is  combined  with  nonrandom
selection.</u>  All  phases  of  body  development  from
embryo  to  adult  exhibit  random  activities  at  the
cellular level, and body formation depends on the new
possibilities  generated  by  these  activities 
<u>irrelevant with selection of those outcomes that satisfy
previously  built- in  criteria.</u>  Always  new  structure  is
based on old structure, and at every stage selection
favors some cells and eliminates others. The survivors
serve  to  produce  new  cells  that  <u>undergo  further
rounds  of  selection.</u>  Except  in  the  immune  system,
cells  and  extensions  of  cells  are  not  genetically
selected  during  development,  but  rather,  are 
<u>positionally  selected.</u>  Those  in  the  right  place  that
make the right connections are stimulated, and those
that don’t are  <u>eliminated.</u> This process is much like
sculpting.  A  natural  consequence  of  the  strategy  is
great variability from individual to individual at the cell
and  molecular  levels,  even  though  large -scale
structures are quite similar.

In  order  to  bring  the  ever-increasing  costs  of  home
care  for  elderly  and  needy  persons  under  control,
managers  of  home  care  providers  have  introduced
management systems. These systems specify tasks of
home care workers and the time and budget available
to  perform  these  tasks.  Electronic  reporting  systems
require home care workers to report on their activities
and  the  time  spent,  thus  making  the  distribution  of
time and money <u>obvious and, in the perception of
managers, controllable.</u> This, in the view of managers,
has contributed to the <u>solution of the problem.</u> The
home care workers, <u>in contrast, may perceive their
work not as a set of separate tasks to be performed as
efficiently as possible, but as a service to be provided
to  a  client  with  whom  they  may  have  developed  a
relationship.</u>  This  includes  having  conversations  with
clients  and  enquiring  about  the  person’s  well -being.
Restricted time and the requirement to report may be
perceived as obstacles that <u>keep the workers from
delivering  the  service  that  is  needed.</u>  If  the
management systems are too rigid, this may <u>result
from  home  care  workers  becoming  overloaded  and
demotivated.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
It is a common assumption that most vagrant birds are
ultimately doomed, aside from the  <u>rare cases where
individuals are able to reorientate and return to their
normal ranges.</u> In turn, it is also commonly assumed
that  vagrancy  itself  is  a  relatively  <u>unimportant
biological  phenomenon.</u>  This  is  undoubtedly  true  for
the majority of cases, as the most likely outcome of
any given vagrancy event is that the individual will fail
to  find  enough  resources,  and/or  be  exposed  to 
<u>inhospitable  environmental  conditions,  and  perish.</u>
However, there are many lines of evidence to suggest
that  vagrancy  can,  on  rare  occasions,  dramatically
alter  the  fate  of  populations,  species  or  even  whole
ecosystems. Despite being  <u>frequent, these events
can  be  extremely  important  when  viewed  at  the
timescales  over  which  ecological  and  evolutionary
processes unfold.</u> The most profound consequences of
vagrancy relate to the establishment of new breeding
sites,  new  migration  routes  and  wintering  locations.
Each of these can occur through different mechanisms,
and at different frequencies, and they each have their
own unique  <u>significance.</u>

alter  the  fate  of  populations,  species  or  even  whole
ecosystems. Despite being  <u>frequent, these events
can  be  extremely  important  when  viewed  at  the
timescales  over  which  ecological  and  evolutionary
processes unfold.</u> The most profound consequences of
vagrancy relate to the establishment of new breeding
sites,  new  migration  routes  and  wintering  locations.
Each of these can occur through different mechanisms,
and at different frequencies, and they each have their
own unique  <u>significance.</u>
options:
① <u>rare cases where
individuals are able to reorientate and return to their
normal ranges.</u>

② <u>unimportant
biological  phenomenon.</u>
③ <u>inhospitable  environmental  conditions,  and  perish.</u>

④ <u>frequent, these events
can  be  extremely  important  when  viewed  at  the
timescales  over  which  ecological  and  evolutionary
processes unfold.</u>
⑤ <u>significance.</u>
explanation: 앞에서, '드문 경우에, 무리에서 떨어져 헤매는 것이 개체 수, 종, 심지어 생태계 전체의 운명을 극적으로 바꿀 수 있다 는 것을 시사하는 많은 증거가 있다'고 했으므로, ④ frequent를 'infrequent' 등으로 고쳐야 한다. [변형] ⑤ significance : importance

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Intuition  can  be  great,  but  it  ought  to  be  <u>hard-
earned.</u> Experts, for example, are able to think on their
feet  because  they’ve  invested  thousands  of  hours  in
learning  and  practice:  their  intuition  has  become 
<u>data-driven.</u> Only then are they able to act quickly in
accordance  with  their  internalized  expertise  and
evidence- based  experience.  Yet  most  people  are  not
experts, though they often think they are. Most of us,
especially  when  we  interact  with  others  on  social
media, act with  <u>expert-like speed and conviction,
offering  a  wide  range  of  opinions  on  global  crises,
without the substance of knowledge that supports it.</u>
And thanks to AI, which ensures that our messages
are delivered to an audience more inclined to believing
it, our  <u>delusions of expertise can be reinforced by
our  personal  filter  bubble.</u>  We  have  an  interesting
tendency to find people more open-minded, rational,
and  <u>sensitive when they think just like us.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
The  fast -growing,  tremendous  amount  of  data,
collected  and  stored  in  large  and  numerous  data
repositories, has far  <u>exceeded our human ability for
understanding without powerful tools.</u> As a result, data
collected  in  large  data  repositories  become  “data
tombs”  —  data  archives  that  are  <u>hardly  visited.</u>
Important decisions are often made based not on the
information–rich  data  stored  in  data  repositories  but
rather on a decision maker’s instinct, simply because
the  decision  maker  does  not  have  the  tools  to 
<u>extract  the  valuable  knowledge  hidden  in  the  vast
amounts of data.</u> Efforts have been made to develop
expert  system  and  knowledge-based  technologies,
which typically rely on users or domain experts to 
<u>manually  input  knowledge  into  knowledge  bases.</u>
However, this procedure is likely to cause biases and
errors  and  is  extremely  costly  and  time  consuming.
The  <u>narrowing gap between data and information
calls for the systematic development of tools that can
turn data tombs into “golden nuggets” of knowledge.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Too  many  times  people,  especially  in  today’s
generation,  expect  things  to  just  happen  overnight.
When we have these false expectations, it tends to 
<u>discourage  us  from  continuing  to  move  forward.</u>
Because this is a high tech society, everything we want
has to be within the parameters of our comfort and
convenience. If it doesn’t happen fast enough, we’re
tempted to  <u>lose interest.</u> So many people don’t want
to take the time it  <u>requires to be successful.</u> Success
is  not  a  matter  of  mere  desire;  you  need  to  stop
being  <u>patient in order to achieve it.</u> Have you fallen
prey to impatience? Great achievements require time
and effort; there are no  <u>shortcuts to greatness.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
If you had wanted to create a “self- driving” car in the
1950s, your best option might have been to strap a
brick to the accelerator. Yes, the vehicle would have
been able to  move forward on its own, but it could not
slow down, stop, or turn to avoid barriers. Obviously 
<u>flawless.</u> But does that  mean the entire concept of the
self- driving  car  is  not  worth  pursuing?  No,  it  only
means that at the time we did not yet have the tools
we now  <u>possess to help enable vehicles to operate
both  autonomously  and  safely.</u>  This  once -distant
dream  now  seems  within  our  reach.  It  is  much  the
same story in medicine. Two decades ago, we were still
taping  bricks  to  accelerators.  Today,  we  are
approaching  the  point  where  we  can  begin  to  bring
some  <u>appropriate technology to bear in ways that</u>
<u>advance  our  understanding  of  patients  as  unique
individuals.</u> In fact, many patients are already wearing
devices that  <u>monitor their conditions in real time,
which  allows  doctors  to  talk  to  their  patients  in  a
specific, refined, and feedback -driven way that was not
even possible a decade ago.</u>
* strap: 끈으로 묶다 ** autonomously: 자율적으로

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
We tend to overrate the impact of new technologies in
part because older technologies have become absorbed
into the furniture of our lives, so as to be almost 
<u>invisible.</u>  Take  the  baby  bottle.  Here  is  a  simple
implement that has  <u>reshaped a fundamental human
experience for vast numbers of infants and mothers,
yet it finds no place in our histories of technology.</u> This
technology  might  be  thought  of  as  a  classic  time-
shifting  device,  as  it  enables  mothers  to  exercise 
<u>more control over the timing of feeding.</u> It can also
function  to  save  time,  as  bottle  feeding  allows  for
someone  else  to  <u>take  over  the  mother’s  time.</u>
Potentially, therefore, it has huge implications for the
management of time in everyday life, yet it is hardly 
<u>overlooked in discussions of high-speed society.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Empathy  holds  significant  value  for  both  employers
and  employees,  yet  its  precise  meaning  often  lacks
clarity. Some companies prioritize cognitive empathy,
highlighting  the  importance  of  leaders  <u>embracing
the  perspectives  of  their  team  members  and  clients
during  negotiation  and  decision-making.</u>  Others
emphasize   affective   empathy   and   empathic
concern, stressing the significance of leaders gaining 
<u>credit through genuine care for their employees and
customers.</u>  The  idea  that  successful  companies 
<u>cultivate empathy,  proposed  by  some  consultants,
essentially  points  to  the  importance  of  good  market
research.</u> In  other  words,  an  “empathic”  company
understands the needs and wants of its customers and
seeks  to  <u>overlook those  needs  and  wants.</u>  When
some people speak of design with empathy, what that
translates  to  is  that  companies  should  take  into
account the specific needs of different  <u>populations—
the blind, the deaf, the elderly, non- English speakers,
the color blind, and so on — when designing products.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
The most prevalent problem kids report is that they
feel  like  they  need  to  be  <u>accessible  at  all  times.</u>
Because  technology  allows  for  it,  they  feel  an
obligation. It’s easy for most of us to  <u>relate — you
probably feel the same pressure in your own life!</u> It is
really  <u>challenging to deal with the fact that we’re
human and can’t always respond instantly.</u> For a teen
or tween who’s still learning the ins and outs of social
interactions,  it’s  even  worse.  Here’s  how  this
behavior plays out sometimes: Your child texts one of
his friends, and the friend doesn’t text back right away.
Now it’s  <u>easy for your child to think, “This person
doesn’t want to be my friend anymore!</u>” So he texts
again,  and  again,  and  again  —  “blowing  up  their
phone.” This can be stress- inducing and even read as
aggressive. But you can see how  <u>hard this could
happen.</u>
* tween: (10 ~ 12세 사이의) 십대 초반의 아동

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
For  years,  many  psychologists  have  held  strongly  to
the belief that the key to  <u>solidifying negative health
habits is to change behavior.</u> This, more than values
and attitudes, is the part of personality that is easiest
to  change.  <u>Ingestive  habits  such  as  smoking,
drinking  and  various  eating  behaviors  are  the  most
common  health  concerns  targeted  for  behavioral
changes.</u>  Process addiction  behaviors  (workaholism,
shopaholism,  and  the  like)  fall  into  this  category  as
well.   Mental   imagery   combined   with   power
of  suggestion  was  taken  up  as  the  premise  of
behavioral  <u>therapy to help people change negative

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Emotion  socialization  —  learning  from  other  people
about emotions and how to deal with  <u>them — starts
early in life and plays a foundational role for emotion
regulation   development.</u>   Although   extra- familial
influences,  such  as  peers  or  media,  <u>gain  in
importance  during  adolescence,  parents  remain  the
primary  socialization  agents.</u>  For  example,  their  own
responses  to  emotional  situations  serve  as  a  role
model for emotion regulation, increasing the likelihood
that  their  children  will  show  similar  reactions  in
comparable  situations.  Parental  practices  at  times
when  their  children  are  faced  with  emotional
challenges  also  <u>impact  emotion  regulation
development.</u>  Whereas  direct  soothing  and  directive
guidance  of  what  to  do  are  beneficial  for  younger
children, they may intrude on adolescents’ autonomy
striving. In consequence, adolescents might pull away
from, rather than turn toward, their parents in times of
emotional  crisis,  <u>unless  parental  practices  are
adjusted.</u> More  <u>suitably in adolescence is indirect
support  of  autonomous  emotion  regulation,  such  as
through  interest  in,  as  well  as  awareness  and
nonjudgmental  acceptance  of,  adolescents’  emotional
experiences, and being available when the adolescent
wants to talk.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Dancers often push themselves to the limits of their
physical capabilities. But that push is  <u>misguided if it
is directed toward accomplishing something physically</u> <u>possible.</u> For instance, a tall dancer with long feet
may wish to perform repetitive vertical jumps to fast
music, pointing his feet while in the air and  <u>lowering
his  heels  to  the  floor  between  jumps.</u>  That  may  be
impossible no matter how strong the dancer is. But a
short-footed  dancer  may  have  no  trouble!  Another
dancer may be struggling to complete a half-turn in
the  air.  Understanding  the  <u>connection  between  a
rapid turn rate and the alignment of the body close to
the rotation axis tells her how to accomplish her turn
successfully.</u> In both of these cases, understanding and
working within the constraints imposed by nature and
described  by  physical  laws  allows  dancers  to  work
efficiently,  <u>minimizing potential risk of injury.</u>
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

question: 적절한 것은?
mainText:
We  must  explore  the  relationship  between  children’s
film  production  and  consumption  habits.  The  term
“children’s film” (A) [replies / implies] ownership by
children — their cinema — but films supposedly made
for children have always been consumed by audiences
of  all  ages,  particularly  in  commercial  cinemas.  The
(B)   [considerate   /   considerable]  crossover  in
audience composition for children’s films can be shown
by the fact that, in 2007, eleven Danish children’s and
youth  films  attracted  59  percent  of  theatrical
admissions, and in 2014, German children’s films (C)
[compromised  /  comprised] seven out of the top
twenty  films  at  the  national  box  office.  This
phenomenon corresponds with a broader, international
embrace of what is seemingly children’s culture among
audiences  of  diverse  ages.  The  old  prejudice  that
children’s film is some other realm, separate from (and
forever subordinate to) a more legitimate cinema for
adults is not supported by the realities of consumption:
children’s film is at the heart of contemporary popular
culture.
 <u>implies - considerate - compromised</u> <u>implies - considerable - comprised</u> <u>replies - considerate - comprised</u> <u>replies - considerable - comprised</u> <u>replies - considerable - compromised</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Beethoven’s  drive  to  create  something novel  is  a
reflection  of  his  state  of  <u>curiosity.</u>  Our  brains
experience  a  sense  of  reward  when  we  create
something new in the process of exploring something
 <u>uncertain,  such  as  a  musical  phrase  that  we’ve
never played or heard before.</u> When our curiosity leads
to something novel, the resulting reward brings us a
sense of  <u>pleasure.</u> A number of investigators have
modeled how curiosity influences musical composition.
In the case of Beethoven, computer modeling focused
on  the  thirty- two  piano  sonatas  written  after  age
thirteen revealed that the musical patterns found in all
of  Beethoven’s  music  <u>decreased  in  later  sonatas,
while  novel  patterns,  including  patterns  that  were
unique  to  a  particular  sonata,  increased.</u>  In  other
words, Beethoven’s music became  <u>more predictable
over time as his curiosity drove the exploration of new
musical ideas.</u> Curiosity is a powerful driver of human
creativity.

explanation: more → less: 앞에서 모든 음악에서 발견되는 음 악 패턴이 후기 소나타에서는 감소한 반면, 새로운 패턴이 증가하 였다고 했으므로, 베토벤의 호기심이 새로운 음악적 아이디어의 탐구를 이끌게 됨에 따라, 그의 음악은 시간이 지날 수록 '덜' 예측 가능하게 되었다가 적절하다. 그러므로 more(더)를 less(덜)로 바꾸어야 한다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Technologists  are  always  on  the  lookout  for 
<u>quantifiable metrics.</u> Measurable inputs to a model are
their lifeblood, and like a social scientist, a technologist
needs to identify concrete measures, or “proxies,” for
assessing progress. This need for quantifiable proxies
produces a bias toward measuring things that are 
<u>easy  to  quantify.</u>  But  simple  metrics  can  take  us
further away from the important goals we really care
about, which may require  <u>complicated metrics or be
extremely difficult, or perhaps impossible, to reduce to
any measure.</u> And when we have  <u>imperfect or bad
proxies, we can easily fall under the illusion that we
are  solving  for  a  good  end  without  actually  making
genuine  progress  toward  a  worthy  solution.</u>  The
problem   of   proxies   results   in   technologists
frequently  substituting  what  is  <u>vague  for  what  is
meaningful.</u> As the saying goes, “Not everything that
counts can be counted, and not everything that can be
counted counts.”

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
We  are  the  only  species  that  seasons  its
food,  <u>deliberately altering it with the highly flavored
plant parts we call herbs and spices.</u> It’s quite possible
that  our  taste  for  spices  has  an  evolutionary  root.
Many  spices  have  antibacterial  properties  —  in  fact,
common  seasonings  such  as  garlic,  onion,  and
oregano  <u>promote  the  growth  of  almost  every
bacterium  tested.</u>  And  the  cultures  that  make  the
heaviest use of spices — think of the garlic and black
pepper of Thai food, the ginger and coriander of India,
the  chili  peppers  of  Mexico  —  come  from  warmer
climates, where bacterial spoilage is a  <u>bigger issue.</u>
In contrast, the most  <u>lightly spiced cuisines — those
of Scandinavia and northern Europe — are from cooler
climates.</u>  Our  uniquely  human  attention  to  flavor,  in
this  case  the  flavor  of  spices,  turns  out  to
have  <u>arisen as a matter of life and death.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Development  of  the  human  body  from  a  single  cell
provides many instances of the structural richness that
is  possible  when  the  repeated  production  of  random
variation is combined with  <u>nonrandom selection.</u> All
phases  of  body  development  from  embryo  to  adult
exhibit random activities at the cellular level, and body
formation depends on the new possibilities generated
by  these  activities  coupled  with  selection  of  those
outcomes that  <u>adhere to previously built- in criteria.</u>
Always new structure is based on old structure, and at
every stage selection favors some cells and eliminates
others. The survivors serve to produce new cells that
undergo  further  rounds  of  selection.  Except  in  the
immune system, cells and extensions of cells are not
genetically  selected  during  development,  but  rather,
are  <u>positionally selected.</u> Those in the right place
that make the right connections are stimulated, and
those that don’t are  <u>discarded.</u> This process is much
like sculpting. A natural consequence of the strategy is
great  <u>consistency from individual to individual at the
cell  and  molecular  levels,  even  though  large -scale
structures are quite alike.</u>

explanation: '인간의 신체는 세포 단위에서는 무작위로, 위치상 으로는 일관적으로 발달한다'는 내용이므로, ⑤ consistency(일 관성)을 'variability'(가변성) 또는 'inconsistency'(비일관성) 등 으로 고쳐야 한다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
In order to bring the <u>ever-increasing costs of home
care  for  elderly  and  needy  persons  under  control,
managers  of  home  care  providers  have  introduced
management systems.</u> These systems specify tasks of
home care workers and the time and budget available
to  perform  these  tasks.  Electronic  reporting  systems
require home care workers to report on their activities
and  the  time  spent,  thus  making  the  distribution  of
time and money  <u>visible and, in the perception of
managers,</u> <u>controllable.</u>  This,  in  the  view  of
managers,  has  contributed  to  the  resolution  of  the
problem. The home care workers, on the other hand,
may perceive their work not as a set of  <u>separate
tasks to be performed as efficiently as possible, but as
a service to be provided to a client with whom they
may  have  developed  a  relationship.</u>  This  includes
having conversations with clients and enquiring about
the  person’s  well -being.  Restricted  time  and  the
requirement to report may be perceived as obstacles
that make it impossible to deliver the service that is
needed. If the management systems are too rigid, this
may result in home care workers becoming overloaded
and  <u>overconfident.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
It is a common assumption that most vagrant birds are
ultimately doomed, aside from the  <u>infrequent cases
where individuals are able to reorientate and return to
their  normal  ranges.</u>  In  turn,  it  is  also  commonly
assumed  that  vagrancy  itself  is  a  relatively
 <u>unimportant  biological  phenomenon.</u>  This  is
doubtlessly true for the majority of cases, as the most
likely outcome of any given vagrancy event is that the
individual will fail to find enough resources, and/or be
exposed to  <u>hospitable environmental conditions, and
perish.</u> However, there are many lines of evidence to
suggest  that  vagrancy  can,  on  rare  occasions,
dramatically  <u>alter the fate of populations, species or
even  whole  ecosystems.</u>  Despite  being  rare,  these
events can be extremely important when viewed at the
timescales  over  which  ecological  and  evolutionary
processes unfold. The most profound consequences of
vagrancy  relate  to  the  <u>establishment  of  new
breeding  sites,  new  migration  routes  and  wintering
locations.</u> Each of these can happen through different
mechanisms,  and  at  different  frequencies,  and  they
each have their own unique importance.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Intuition  can  be  great,  but  it  ought  to  be  <u>hard -
earned.</u> Experts, for example, are able to think on their
feet  because  they’ve  invested  thousands  of  hours  in
learning and practice: their intuition has become data-
driven.  Only  then  are  they  able  to  act  quickly  in
accordance  with  their  <u>internalized expertise  and
evidence- based  experience.</u>  Yet  most  people  are  not
experts, though they often think they are. Most of us,
especially  when  we  interact  with  others  on  social
media,  act  with  expert- like  speed  and  conviction, 
<u>offering a  wide  range  of  opinions  on  global  crises,
without the substance of knowledge that supports it.</u>
And thanks to AI, which ensures that our messages
are  delivered  to  an  audience  more  <u>reluctant to
believing  it,  our  delusions  of  expertise  can  be
reinforced by our personal filter bubble.</u> We have an 
<u>interesting tendency to find people more open- minded,
rational, and sensible when they think just like us.</u>

mainText:
The  <u>fast -growing,  tremendous  amount  of  data,
collected  and  stored  in  large  and  numerous  data
repositories,  has  far  exceeded  our  human  ability  for
understanding without powerful tools.</u> As a result, data
collected  in  large  data  repositories  become  “data
tombs” — data archives that are  <u>frequently visited.</u>
Important decisions are often made based not on the
information–rich  data  stored  in  data  repositories  but
rather  on  a  decision  maker’s  <u>instinct,  simply
because the decision maker does not have the tools to
extract the valuable knowledge</u> <u>hidden in the vast
amounts of data.</u> Efforts have been made to develop
expert  system  and  knowledge- based  technologies,
which typically rely on users or domain experts to 
<u>manually  input  knowledge  into  knowledge  bases.</u>
However, this procedure is likely to cause biases and
errors  and  is  extremely  costly  and  time  consuming.
The widening gap between data and information calls
for the systematic development of tools that can turn
data tombs into “golden nuggets” of knowledge.
* repository: 저장소 ** golden nugget: 금괴

Too  many  times  people,  especially  in  today’s
generation,  expect  things  to  just  happen  overnight.
When we have these false expectations, it tends to 
<u>deter  us  from  continuing  to  move  forward.</u>  Because
this is a high tech society, everything we want has to
be  <u>within  the  parameters  of  our  comfort  and
convenience.</u> If it doesn’t happen fast enough, we’re
tempted to  <u>maintain interest.</u> So many people don’t
want to take the time it requires to be  <u>successful.</u>
Success  is  not  a  matter  of  mere  desire;  you  should
develop  <u>perseverance in order to achieve it.</u> Have
you fallen prey to impatience? Great things take time
to build.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
If you had wanted to create a “self- driving” car in the
1950s, your best option might have been to strap a
brick to the accelerator. Yes,  <u>the vehicle would have
been unable to move forward on its own, but it could
not  slow  down,  stop,  or  turn  to  avoid  barriers.</u>
Obviously not ideal. But  <u>does that  mean the entire
concept of the self- driving car is not worth pursuing?</u>
No, it only means that at the time  <u>we did not yet
have the tools we now possess to help enable vehicles
to operate both autonomously and safely.</u> This once -
distant dream now seems within our reach. It is much
the same story in medicine. Two decades ago,  <u>we
were still taping bricks to accelerators.</u> Today, we are
approaching  the  point  where  we  can  begin  to  bring
some  appropriate  technology  to  bear  in  ways  that
advance  our  understanding  of  patients  as  unique
individuals.  In  fact,  <u>many  patients  are  already
wearing devices that monitor their conditions in real
time, which allows doctors to talk to their patients in a
specific, refined, and feedback -driven way that was not
even possible a decade ago.</u>
* strap: 끈으로 묶다 ** autonomously: 자율적으로
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

mainText:
We tend to overrate the impact of new technologies in
part  because  older  technologies  have  become (A)
[detached  from  /  integrated  into] the furniture of
our lives, so as to be almost invisible. Take the baby
bottle.  Here  is  a  simple  implement  that  has
transformed a fundamental human experience for vast
numbers  of  infants  and  mothers,  yet  it  is  not (B)
[omitted  /  included] in our histories of technology.
This technology might be thought of as a classic time-
shifting device, as it enables mothers to exercise more
control over the timing of feeding. It can also function
to (C) [save / waste] time, as bottle feeding allows
for someone else to substitute for the mother’s time.
Potentially, therefore, it has huge implications for the
management of time in everyday life, yet it is entirely
overlooked in discussions of high-speed society.
 <u>integrated into - omitted - waste</u> <u>integrated into - included - save</u> <u>detached from - included - waste</u> <u>detached from - included - save</u> <u>detached from - omitted - save

(C) '젖병 수 유는 시간을 절약하는 기능도 하다'가 흐름상 자연스러우므로, save(절약하다)가 적절하다. waste는 '낭비하다'라는 뜻이다.

Empathy is frequently listed as one of the most desired
skills  in  an  employer  or  employee,  although  without
specifying  exactly  what  is  meant  by  empathy.  Some
businesses  stress (A)   [cognitive   /   affective]
empathy,  emphasizing  the  need  for  leaders  to
understand  the  perspective  of  employees  and
customers  when  negotiating  deals  and  making
decisions. Others stress (B)  [cognitive  /  affective]
empathy  and  empathic  concern,  emphasizing  the
ability  of  leaders  to  gain  trust  from  employees  and
customers  by  treating  them  with  real  concern  and
compassion.  When  some  consultants  argue  that
successful  companies  foster  empathy,  what  that
translates  to  is  that  companies  should  conduct  good
market  research.  In  other  words,  an  “empathic”
company  understands  the  needs  and  wants  of  its
customers and seeks to fulfill those needs and wants.
When  some  people  speak  of  design  with  empathy,
what that translates to is that companies should take
into account the (C)  [specific  /  general] needs of
different populations — the blind, the deaf, the elderly,
non English speakers, the color blind, and so on — when
designing products.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
The most prevalent problem kids report is that they
feel  like  they  need  to  be  <u>accessible  at  all  times.</u>
Because  technology  allows  for  it,  they  feel  an 
<u>obligation.</u>  It’s  easy  for  most  of  us  to  relate  —  you
probably feel the same pressure in your own life! It is
really  challenging  to  deal  with  the  fact  that  we’re
human and can’t always respond  <u>immediately.</u> For a
teen  or  tween  who’s  still  learning  the  ins  and  outs
of social interactions, it’s even  <u>worse.</u> Here’s how
this  behavior  plays  out  sometimes:  Your  child  texts
one  of  his  friends,  and  the  friend  doesn’t  text  back
right away. Now it’s easy for your child to think, “This
person doesn’t want to be my friend anymore!” So he
texts again, and again, and again — “blowing up their
phone.” This can be stress- inducing and even read as
 <u>gentle.</u>  But  you  can  see  how  easily  this  could
happen.

mainText:
For  years,  many  psychologists  have  held  strongly  to
the belief that the key to addressing  <u>negative health
habits is to change behavior.</u> This, more than values
and  attitudes,  is  the  part  of  personality  that  is 
<u>easiest to change.</u> Ingestive habits such as smoking,
drinking  and  various  eating  behaviors  are  the  most
common  health  concerns  targeted  for  behavioral
changes.  Process addiction  behaviors  (workaholism,
shopaholism,  and  the  like)  fall  into  this  category  as
well.  Mental  imagery  <u>combined  with  power
of  suggestion  was  taken  up  as  the  premise  of
behavioral  medicine  to  help  people  change  negative
health  behaviors  into  positive  ones.</u>  Although  this
technique alone will not produce changes, when used
 <u>alongside  other  behavior  modification  tactics  and
coping  strategies,  behavioral  changes  have  proved
effective for some people.</u> What mental imagery does
is reinforce a new  <u>improper behavior.</u> Repeated use
of  images  reinforces  the  desired  behavior  more
strongly over time.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Emotion  socialization  —  learning  from  other  people
about emotions and how to deal with them — starts
early  in  life  and  plays  a  <u>foundational  role  for
emotion  regulation  development.</u>  Although  extra- -
familial  influences,  such  as  peers  or  media,  gain  in
importance during adolescence, parents remain the 
<u>primary  socialization  agents.</u>  For  example,  their  own
responses  to  emotional  situations  serve  as  a  role
model for emotion regulation, increasing the likelihood
that their children will show  <u>different reactions in
comparable  situations.</u>  Parental  practices  at  times
when  their  children  are  faced  with  emotional
challenges   also   impact   emotion   regulation
development.  Whereas  direct  soothing  and  directive
guidance  of  what  to  do  are  beneficial  for  younger
children,  they  may  <u>intrude  on  adolescents’
autonomy striving.</u> In consequence, adolescents might
pull away from, rather than turn toward, their parents
in times of emotional crisis, unless parental practices
are  adjusted.  More  suitable  in  adolescence  is 
<u>indirect  support  of  autonomous  emotion  regulation,
such as through interest in, as well as awareness and
nonjudgmental  acceptance  of,  adolescents’  emotional
experiences, and being available when the adolescent
wants to talk.</u>

Dancers often push themselves to the limits of their
physical capabilities. But that push is  <u>misguided if it
is directed toward accomplishing something physically
impossible.</u> For instance, a tall dancer with long feet
may wish to perform repetitive vertical jumps to fast
music, pointing his feet while in the air and lowering
his heels to the floor between jumps. That may be 
<u>possible  no  matter  how  strong  the  dancer  is.</u>  But  a
short-footed  dancer  may  have  no  trouble!  Another
dancer may be struggling to  <u>complete a half-turn in
the air.</u> Understanding the connection between a rapid
turn rate and the alignment of the body  <u>close to the
rotation  axis  tells  her  how  to  accomplish  her  turn
successfully.</u> In both of these cases, understanding and
working within the constraints imposed by nature and
described  by  physical  laws  allows  dancers  to  work
efficiently,  <u>minimizing potential risk of injury.</u>
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

question: 적절한 것은?
mainText:
We  must  explore  the  relationship  between  children’s
film  production  and  consumption  habits.  The  term
“children’s film” implies ownership by children — their
cinema — but films supposedly made for children have
always  been  consumed  by  audiences  of  all  ages,
particularly  in  commercial  cinemas.  The (A)
[insignificant / considerable] crossover in audience
composition for children’s films can be shown by the
fact that, in 2007, eleven Danish children’s and youth
films attracted 59 percent of theatrical admissions, and
in 2014, German children’s films comprised seven out
of the top twenty films at the national box office. This
phenomenon (B) [contradict / corresponds] with a
broader,  international  embrace  of  what  is  seemingly
children’s  culture  among  audiences  of  diverse  ages.
The  old  prejudice  that  children’s  film  is  some  other
realm, (C)  [separate  /  incorporate]  from  (and
forever subordinate to) a more legitimate cinema for
adults is not supported by the realities of consumption:
children’s film is at the heart of contemporary popular
culture.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Beethoven’s drive to create something  <u>novel is a
reflection  of  his  state  of  curiosity.</u>  Our  brains
experience  a  sense  of  reward  when  we  create
something new in the process of exploring something
 <u>uncertain,  such  as  a  musical  phrase  that  we’ve
never played or heard before.</u> When our curiosity leads
to something novel, the resulting reward brings us a
sense of  <u>pleasure.</u> A number of investigators have
modeled how curiosity influences musical composition.
In the case of Beethoven, computer modeling focused
on  the  thirty- two  piano  sonatas  written  after  age
thirteen revealed that the musical patterns found in all
of Beethoven’s music decreased in later sonatas, while
novel patterns, including patterns that were unique to
a  particular  sonata,  <u>increased.</u>  In  other  words,
Beethoven’s music became  <u>more predictable over
time  as  his  curiosity  drove  the  exploration  of  new
musical ideas.</u> Curiosity is a powerful driver of human
creativity.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Technologists  are  always  on  the  lookout  for 
<u>quantifiable metrics.</u> Measurable inputs to a model are
their lifeblood, and like a social scientist, a technologist
needs to  <u>identify concrete measures, or “proxies,”
for  assessing  progress.</u>  This  need  for  quantifiable
proxies produces a bias toward measuring things that
are easy to quantify. But simple metrics can take us
further  <u>to the important goals we really care about,
which  may  require  complicated  metrics  or  be
extremely difficult, or perhaps impossible, to reduce to
any measure.</u> And when we have  <u>imperfect or bad
proxies, we can easily fall under the illusion that we
are  solving  for  a  good  end  without  actually  making
genuine  progress  toward  a  worthy  solution.</u>  The
problem  of  proxies  results  in  technologists 
<u>frequently substituting what is measurable for what is
meaningful.</u> As the saying goes, “Not everything that
counts can be counted, and not everything that can be
counted counts.”

for  assessing  progress.</u>  This  need  for  quantifiable
proxies produces a bias toward measuring things that
are easy to quantify. But simple metrics can take us
further  <u>to the important goals we really care about,
which  may  require  complicated  metrics  or  be
extremely difficult, or perhaps impossible, to reduce to
any measure.</u> And when we have  <u>imperfect or bad
proxies, we can easily fall under the illusion that we
are  solving  for  a  good  end  without  actually  making
genuine  progress  toward  a  worthy  solution.</u>  The
problem  of  proxies  results  in  technologists 
<u>frequently substituting what is measurable for what is
meaningful.</u> As the saying goes, “Not everything that
counts can be counted, and not everything that can be
counted counts.”
options: ① <u>quantifiable metrics.</u>

② <u>identify concrete measures, or “proxies,”
for  assessing  progress.</u>

③ <u>to the important goals we really care about,
which  may  require  complicated  metrics  or  be
extremely difficult, or perhaps impossible, to reduce to
any measure.</u>

④ <u>imperfect or bad
proxies, we can easily fall under the illusion that we
are  solving  for  a  good  end  without  actually  making
genuine  progress  toward  a  worthy  solution.</u>

⑤ <u>frequently substituting what is measurable for what is
meaningful.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
In  order  to  bring  the  ever-increasing  costs  of  home
care  for  elderly  and  needy  persons  under  control,
managers of home care providers have  <u>introduced
management systems.</u> These systems specify tasks of
home care workers and the time and budget available
to  perform  these  tasks.  Electronic  reporting  systems
require home care workers to report on their activities
and  the  time  spent,  thus  making  the  distribution  of
time and money  <u>invisible and, in the perception of
managers, controllable.</u> This, in the view of managers,
has contributed to the resolution of the problem. The
home  care  workers,  on  the  other  hand,  may 
<u>perceive their work not as a set of separate tasks to be
performed as efficiently as possible, but as a service to
be  provided  to  a  client  with  whom  they  may  have
developed  a  relationship.</u>  This  includes  having
conversations with clients and  <u>enquiring about the
person’s  well -being.</u>  Restricted  time  and  the
requirement to report may be perceived as obstacles
that make it impossible to deliver the service that is
needed. If the management systems are too  <u>rigid,
this  may  result  in  home  care  workers  becoming
overloaded and demotivated.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
It is a common assumption that most vagrant birds are
ultimately doomed, aside from the rare cases where
individuals are able to reorientate and return to their
normal ranges. In turn, it is also commonly assumed
that   vagrancy   itself   is   a   relatively 
<u>irrelevant biological phenomenon.</u> This is undoubtedly
true  for  the  majority  of  cases,  as  the  most  likely
outcome  of  any  given  vagrancy  event  is  that  the
individual will fail to find enough resources, and/or be
exposed to  <u>hospitable environmental conditions, and
perish.</u> However, there are many lines of evidence to
suggest    that    vagrancy    can,    on    rare
occasions,  dramatically  alter  the  fate  of  populations,
species  or  even  entire  ecosystems.  Despite  being 
<u>infrequent, these events can be extremely important
when viewed at the timescales over which ecological
and evolutionary processes</u> <u>stretch out.</u> The most
profound  consequences  of  vagrancy  relate  to  the
establishment  of  new  breeding  sites,  new  migration
routes and wintering locations. Each of these can occur
through  different  mechanisms,  and  at  different
frequencies,  and  they  each  have  their  own 
<u>distinctive importance.</u>

reinforced  by  our  personal  filter  bubble.</u>  We  have  an
interesting tendency to find people more open-minded,

to ours.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
If you had wanted to create a “self- driving” car in the
1950s, your best option might have been to strap a
brick to the accelerator. Yes, the vehicle would have
been able to  move forward on its own, but it could not
slow down, stop, or turn to  <u>avoid barriers.</u> Obviously
not ideal. But does that  mean the entire concept of
the self- driving car is not worth  <u>pursuing?</u> No, it
only means that at the time we did not yet have the
tools  we  now  possess  to  help  enable  vehicles  to
operate  both  autonomously  and  safely.  This  once -
distant dream now seems  <u>within our reach.</u> It is
much the same story in medicine. Two decades ago,
we were still  <u>taping bricks to accelerators.</u> Today, we
are approaching the point where we can begin to bring
some appropriate technology to bear in ways that 
<u>diminish  our  understanding  of  patients  as  unique
individuals.</u> In fact, many patients are already wearing
devices  that  monitor  their  conditions  in  real  time,
which  allows  doctors  to  talk  to  their  patients  in  a
specific, refined, and feedback -driven way that was not
even possible a decade ago.
* strap: 끈으로 묶다 ** autonomously: 자율적으로

We  tend  to  <u>overestimate  the  impact  of  new
technologies in part because older technologies have
become absorbed into the furniture of our lives, so as
to be almost invisible.</u> Take the baby bottle. Here is a
simple  <u>tool  that  has  transformed  a  fundamental
human  experience  for  vast  numbers  of  infants  and
mothers,  yet  it  finds  no  place  in  our  histories  of
technology.</u> This technology might be thought of as a
classic time-shifting  device, as it enables mothers to
exercise more  <u>control over the timing of feeding.</u> It
can also function to save time, as bottle feeding allows
for  someone  else  to  <u>substitute  for  the  mother’s
time.</u> Potentially, therefore, it has huge implications for
the  management  of  time  in  everyday  life,  yet  it  is
entirely  <u>admired  in  discussions  of  high-speed
society.</u>

<u>desired  skills  in  an  employer  or  employee,  although
without specifying exactly what is meant by empathy.</u>
Some  businesses  stress  cognitive  empathy, 
<u>emphasizing  the  need  for  leaders  to  understand  the
perspective  of  employees  and  customers  when
negotiating deals and making decisions.</u> Others stress
affective empathy and empathic concern, emphasizing
the ability of leaders to gain  <u>trust from employees
and customers by treating them with real concern and
compassion.</u>   When   some   consultants   argue
that successful companies  <u>suppress empathy, what
that  translates  to  is  that  companies  should  conduct
good market research.</u> In other words, an “empathic”
company  understands  the  needs  and  wants  of  its
customers and seeks to fulfill those needs and wants.
When  some  people  speak  of  design  with  empathy,
what  that  <u>translates  to  is  that  companies
should take into account the specific needs of different
populations  —  the  blind,  the  deaf,  the  elderly,  non -
English  speakers,  the  color blind,  and  so  on  —  when

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
The most prevalent problem kids report is that they feel
like they need to be  <u>accessible at all times.</u> Because
technology allows for it, they feel an  <u>obligation.</u> It's
easy for most of us to relate ─ you probably feel the
same pressure in your own life! It is really  <u>easy to
deal with the fact that we're human and can't always
respond instantly.</u> For a teen or tween who's still learning
the ins and outs of social interactions, it's even  <u>worse.</u>
Here's how this behavior plays out sometimes: Your child
texts one of his friends, and the friend doesn't text back
right away. Now it's easy for your child to think, "This
person doesn't want to be my friend anymore!" So he
texts again, and again, and again ─ "blowing up their
phone." This can be stress-inducing and even read as 
<u>aggressive.</u>  But  you  can  see  how  easily  this  could
happen.
*tween: (10~12세 사이의) 십대 초반의 아동

For  years,  many  psychologists  have  held  strongly  to
the belief that the key to  <u>addressing negative health
habits is to change behavior.</u> This, more than values
and attitudes, is the part of personality that is easiest
to change. Ingestive habits such as smoking, drinking
and  various  eating  behaviors  are  the  most  common
health  concerns  <u>targeted  for  behavioral  changes.</u>
Process- addiction behaviors (workaholism,
shopaholism, and the like)  <u>fall into this category as
well.</u>   Mental   imagery   combined   with   power
of  suggestion  was  taken  up  as  the  premise  of
behavioral  medicine  to  help  people  change  negative
health  behaviors  into  positive  ones.  Although  this
technique  alone  will  not  <u>produce  changes,  when
used alongside other behavior modification tactics and
coping  strategies,  behavioral  changes  have  proved
effective for some people.</u> What mental imagery does
is  <u>deteriorate a new desired behavior.</u> Repeated use
of  images  reinforces  the  desired  behavior  more
strongly over time.
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

question: 적절한 것은?
mainText:
Dancers often push themselves to the limits of their
(A) [physical / physiological] capabilities. But that
push is misguided if it is directed toward accomplishing
something  physically  impossible.  For  instance,  a  tall
dancer with long feet may wish to perform repetitive
vertical jumps to fast music, pointing his feet while in
the  air  and  lowering  his  heels  to  the  floor  between
jumps. That may be (B) [impossible / possible] no
matter how strong the dancer is. But a short-footed
dancer may have no trouble! Another dancer may be
struggling  to  complete  a  half-turn  in  the  air.
Understanding  the  connection  between  a  rapid  turn
rate  and  the  alignment  of  the  body  close  to  the
rotation  axis  tells  her  how  to  accomplish  her  turn
successfully. In both of these cases, understanding and
working within the constraints imposed by nature and
described  by  physical  laws  allows  dancers  to  work
efficiently, (C) [minimizing / maximizing] potential
risk of injury.

question: 적절한 것은?
mainText:
We  must  explore  the  relationship  between  children’s
film  production  and  consumption  habits.  The  term
“children’s film” implies ownership by children — their
cinema — but films supposedly made for children have
always  been  consumed  by  audiences  of  all  ages,
particularly  in  commercial  cinemas.  The (A)
[considerable / considerate] crossover in audience
composition for children’s films can be shown by the
fact that, in 2007, eleven Danish children’s and youth
films attracted 59 percent of theatrical admissions, and
in 2014, German children’s films comprised seven out
of the top twenty films at the national box office. This
phenomenon corresponds with a broader, international
embrace of what is seemingly children’s culture among
audiences  of  diverse  ages.  The  old  prejudice  that
children’s film is some other realm, separate from (and
forever subordinate to) a more legitimate cinema for
adults  is  not (B)  [supported  /  opposed]  by  the
realities of consumption: children’s film is (C) [on the
edge  /  at  the  heart]  of  contemporary  popular
culture.
* subordinate: 하위의

Beethoven’s  drive  to  create  something  novel  is  a 
<u>reflection  of  his  state  of  curiosity.</u>  Our  brains
experience  a  sense  of  reward  when  we  create
something new in the process of exploring something
 <u>uncertain,  such  as  a  musical  phrase  that  we’ve
never played or heard before.</u> When our curiosity leads
to something novel, the resulting reward brings us a
sense  of  pleasure.  A  number  of  investigators  have
modeled  how  curiosity  <u>influences  musical
composition.</u>  In  the  case  of  Beethoven,  computer
modeling  focused  on  the  thirty- two  piano  sonatas
written  after  age  thirteen  revealed  that  the  musical
patterns found in all of Beethoven’s music  <u>decreased
in  later  sonatas,  while  novel  patterns,  including
patterns  that  were  unique  to  a  particular  sonata,
increased.</u> In other words, Beethoven’s music became
 <u>more predictable over time as his curiosity drove
the  exploration  of  new  musical  ideas.</u>  Curiosity  is  a
powerful driver of human creativity.
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

mainText:
Technologists  are  always  on  the  lookout  for
quantifiable metrics. Measurable inputs to a model are
their lifeblood, and like a social scientist, a technologist
needs to identify definite measures, or “proxies,” for
assessing progress. This need for quantifiable proxies
produces a bias toward measuring things that are (A)
[easy / difficult] to quantify. But simple metrics can
take  us  further  away  from  the  important  goals  we
really care about, which may require (B)  [simple  /
complicated]  metrics  or  be  extremely  difficult,  or
perhaps  impossible,  to  reduce  to  any  measure.  And
when we have imperfect or bad proxies, we can easily
fall under the illusion that we are solving for a good
end without actually making authentic progress toward
a  worthy  solution.  The  problem  of  proxies  results  in
technologists   frequently   substituting   what   is
measurable  for  what  is (C)   [meaningful /
meaningless].  As  the  saying  goes,  “Not  everything
that counts can be counted, and not everything that
can be counted counts.”
 <u>easy - complicated - meaningless</u> <u>easy - simple - meaningful</u> <u>easy - complicated - meaningful</u> <u>difficult - simple - meaningful</u> <u>difficult - complicated - meaningless</u>

mainText:
We  are  the  only  species  that  seasons  its  food,
deliberately  <u>preserving it with the highly flavored
plant parts we call herbs and spices.</u> It’s quite possible
that  our  taste  for  spices  has  an  evolutionary  root.
Many  spices  have  antibacterial  properties  —  in  fact,
common seasonings such as garlic, onion, and oregano
 <u>inhibit the growth of almost every bacterium tested.</u>
And the cultures that make the heaviest use of spices
— think of the garlic and black pepper of Thai food, the
ginger  and  coriander  of  India,  the  chili  peppers  of
Mexico  —  come  from  <u>warmer  climates,  where
bacterial  spoilage  is  a  bigger  issue.</u>  In  contrast,  the
most  <u>lightly spiced cuisines — those of Scandinavia
and northern Europe — are from cooler climates.</u> Our
uniquely  human  attention  to  flavor,  in  this  case  the
flavor of spices, turns out to have  <u>arisen as a matter
of life and death.</u>

mainText:
Development  of  the  human  body  from  a  single  cell
provides many examples of the structural  <u>richness
that  is  possible  when  the  repeated  production  of
random  variation  is  combined  with  nonrandom
selection.</u> All  phases  of  body  development  from
embryo  to  adult  exhibit  random  activities  at  the
cellular level, and body formation depends on the new
possibilities generated by these activities coupled with
selection of those outcomes that satisfy previously 
<u>built- in criteria.</u> Always new structure is based on old
structure,  and  at  every  stage  selection  favors  some
cells  and  eliminates  others. The  survivors  serve  to
produce  <u>new cells that undergo further rounds of
selection.</u>  Except  in  the  immune  system,  cells  and
extensions of cells are not genetically selected during
development, but rather, are  <u>positionally selected.</u> 
Those  in  the  right  place  that  make  the  right
connections are stimulated, and those that don’t are
eliminated.  This  process  is  much  like  sculpting.  A
natural consequence of the strategy is great variability
from individual to individual at the cell and molecular
levels, even though large -scale structures are quite 
<u>different.</u>
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

In  order  to  bring  the  ever-increasing  costs  of  home
care  for  elderly  and  needy  persons  under  control,
managers  of  home  care  providers  have  introduced
management   systems.   These   systems (A)
[complicate  /  specify] tasks of home care workers
and the time and budget available to perform these
tasks. Electronic reporting systems require home care
workers  to  report  on  their  activities  and  the  time
spent, thus making the distribution of time and money
(B) [visible / ambiguous] and, in the perception of
managers, controllable. This, in the view of managers,
has contributed to the resolution of the problem. The
home care workers, on the other hand, may perceive
their  work  not  as  a  set  of  separate  tasks  to  be
performed as efficiently as possible, but as a service to
be  provided  to  a  client  with  whom  they  may  have
developed  a  relationship.  This  includes  having
conversations  with  clients  and  enquiring  about  the
person’s  well -being.  Restricted  time  and  the
requirement  to  report  may  be  perceived  as (C)
[guidelines  /  obstacles] that make it impossible to
deliver the service that is needed. If the management
systems are too rigid, this may result in home care
workers becoming overloaded and demotivated.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
It is a common assumption that most vagrant birds are
ultimately doomed, aside from the rare cases where
individuals are able to reorientate and return to their
 <u>normal  ranges.</u>  In  turn,  it  is  also  commonly
assumed  that  vagrancy  itself  is  a  relatively 
<u>trivial biological phenomenon.</u> This is undoubtedly true
for the majority of cases, as the most likely outcome of
any given vagrancy event is that the individual will fail
to  find  enough  resources,  and/or  be  exposed  to 
<u>inhospitable  environmental  conditions,  and  perish.</u>
However, there are many lines of evidence to suggest
that vagrancy can, on rare occasions, dramatically 
<u>change the fate of populations, species or even whole
ecosystems.</u>  Despite  being  infrequent,  these  events
can be extremely  <u>insignificant when viewed at the
timescales  over  which  ecological  and  evolutionary
processes unfold.</u> The most profound consequences of
vagrancy relate to the establishment of new breeding
sites,  new  migration  routes  and  wintering  locations.
Each of these can occur through different mechanisms,
and at different frequencies, and they each have their
own unique importance.

explanation: 새들이 무리에서 떨어져 헤매는 것이 개체 수, 종, 심지어 생태계 전체의 운명을 바꿀 수 있다고 설명하고 있으므로, 이러한 경우들(these event)은 생태학적, 진화적인 시간의 관점 에서 볼 때 매우 '중요한' 경우라고 볼 수 있다. 따라서 ⑤ insignificant(대수롭지 않은)을 significant나 important(중요 한) 등으로 고쳐야 한다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Intuition can be great, but it ought to be hard-earned.
Experts, for example, are able to think on their feet
because  they’ve  invested  thousands  of  hours  in
learning  and  practice:  their  intuition  has  become 
<u>data-driven.</u> Only then are they able to act quickly in
accordance  with  their  <u>internalized  expertise  and
evidence- based  experience.</u>  Yet  most  people  are  not
experts, though they often think they are. Most of us,
especially  when  we  interact  with  others  on  social
media,  act  with  expert-like  speed  and  conviction,
offering  a  wide  range  of  opinions  on  global  crises,
without the substance of knowledge that  <u>supports it.</u>
And thanks to AI, which ensures that our messages
are  delivered  to  an  audience  more  <u>reluctant  to
believe it, our delusions of expertise can be reinforced
by our personal filter bubble.</u> We have an interesting
tendency to find people more open-minded, rational,
and sensible when they think just  <u>like us.</u>

mainText:
The fast-growing, tremendous amount of data, collected
and stored in large and numerous data repositories, has
far  <u>exceeded our  human  ability  for  understanding
without powerful tools.</u> As a result, data collected in large
data repositories become "data tombs" ─ data archives
that are  <u>hardly visited.</u> Important decisions are often
made based not on the information-rich data stored in
data  repositories  but  rather  on  a  decision  maker's 
<u>instinct,  simply  because  the  decision  maker  does  not
have  the  tools  to  extract  the  valuable  knowledge</u>
<u>hidden in the vast amounts of data.</u> Efforts have been
made  to  develop  expert  system  and  knowledge-based

consuming.</u>  The  widening  gap  between  data  and

that  can  turn  data  tombs  into  "golden  nuggets"  of
knowledge.

move  forward.  Because  this  is  a  high  tech  society,
everything we want has to be within the parameters of
our   comfort   and (B) [convenience /
inconvenience].  If  it  doesn’t  happen  fast  enough,
we’re tempted to lose interest. So many people don’t
want  to  take  the  time  it  requires  to  be  successful.

develop patience in order to achieve it. Have you fallen
prey to (C)  [impatience  /  patience]? Great things
take time to build.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
We  tend  to  <u>exaggerate the  impact  of  new
technologies in part because older technologies have
become absorbed into the furniture of our lives, so as
to be almost</u> <u>noticeable.</u> Take the baby bottle. Here
is  a  simple  implement  that  has  transformed  a
fundamental  human  experience  for  vast  numbers  of
infants  and  mothers,  yet  it  finds  no  place  in  our
histories  of  technology.  This  technology  might  be
thought  of  as  a  classic  time-shifting    device,  as  it
enables mothers to exercise  <u>more control over the
timing of feeding.</u> It can also function to save time, as
bottle feeding allows for someone else to  <u>substitute
for  the  mother’s  time.</u>  Potentially,  therefore,  it  has
huge  implications  for  the  management  of  time  in
everyday  life,  yet  it  is  entirely  <u>overlooked in
discussions of high-speed society.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Empathy  is  frequently  listed  as  one  of  the  most 
<u>preferred skills in an employer or employee, although
without specifying exactly what is meant by empathy.</u>
Some  businesses  stress  <u>cognitive  empathy,
emphasizing  the  need  for  leaders  to  understand  the
perspective  of  employees  and  customers  when
negotiating deals and making decisions.</u> Others stress
 <u>affective    empathy    and    empathic
concern, emphasizing  the  ability  of  leaders  to  gain
trust from employees and customers by treating them
with  real  concern  and  compassion.</u>  When  some
consultants  argue  that  successful  companies 
<u>promote  empathy,  what  that  translates  to  is  that
companies  should  conduct  good  market  research.</u>
In other words, an “empathic” company understands
the needs and wants of its customers and seeks to 
<u>dismiss  those  needs  and  wants.</u>  When  some  people
speak of design with empathy, what that translates to
is that companies should take into account the specific
needs of different populations — the blind, the deaf,
the elderly, non- English speakers, the color- blind, and
so on — when designing products.
*empathy: 공감, 공감능력  **compassion 동정심

The most  <u>prevalent problem kids report is that they
feel like they need to be</u> <u>inaccessible at all times.</u>
Because  technology  allows  for  it,  they  feel  an 
<u>obligation.</u>  It’s  easy  for  most  of  us  to  relate  —  you
probably feel the same pressure in your own life! It is
really  challenging  to  deal  with  the  fact  that  we’re
human  and  can’t  always  respond  <u>instantly.</u>  For  a
teen  or  tween  who’s  still  learning  the  ins  and  outs
of social interactions, it’s even worse. Here’s how this
behavior plays out sometimes: Your child texts one of
his friends, and the friend doesn’t text back right away.
Now  it’s  easy  for  your  child  to  think,  “This  person
doesn’t want to be my friend anymore!” So he texts
again,  and  again,  and  again  —  “blowing  up  their
phone.” This can be stress- inducing and even read as
 <u>aggressive.</u> But you can see how easily this could
happen.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
For years, many psychologists have held strongly to the
belief that the key to addressing negative health habits is
to  <u>change behavior.</u> This is the part of personality that
is  easiest  to  change,  more  than  values  and  attitudes.
Ingestive habits such as smoking, drinking and various
eating behaviors are the most common health concerns
targeted  for  behavioral  changes.  Process-addiction
behaviors (workaholism, shopaholism, and the like) fall
into this category as well. Mental imagery combined with
power  of  suggestion  was  taken  up  as  the  premise  of
behavioral medicine to help people turn negative health
behaviors into  <u>positive ones.</u> Although this technique
alone  will  not  produce  changes,  when  used  alongside
other behavior modification tactics and coping strategies,
behavioral changes have proved  <u>successful in some
people.</u> What mental imagery does is  <u>inhibit a new
desired  behavior.</u>  Repeated  use  of  images  strengthens
the desired behavior more  <u>strongly over time.</u>
