question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Dancers often  <u>exert themselves to the limits of their
physical capabilities.</u> But that push is  <u>injudicious if it is
directed  toward  accomplishing  something  physically
impossible.</u> For instance, a tall dancer with long feet may
wish to perform repetitive vertical jumps to fast music,
pointing his feet while in the air and lowering his heels to
the  floor  between  jumps.  That  may  be  impossible  no
matter  how  strong  the  dancer  is.  But  a  short-footed
dancer may not have any  <u>ease.</u> Pull it off! Another
dancer may be struggling to complete a half-turn in the
air. Understanding the connection between a rapid turn
rate and the alignment of the body close to the rotation
axis  tells  her  how  she  <u>carries  out her  turn
successfully.</u> In both of these cases, understanding and
working within the imposed by nature and described by
physical laws allows dancers to work efficiently, which 
<u>cuts back on potential risk of injury.</u>
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

(A) '어린이 영화의 관객 구성에서 상당한 (연령 간의) 넘나듦이 있다는 것은, ~ 했다는 사실에 의해 분명히 [증명될] 수 있다.'가 흐름상 적절하므로, 'demonstrated'(증명 된)이 적절하다. contradict 반박하다. (B) '이 현상은 다양한 연 령대의 관객들 사이에서 겉으로는 어린이 문화처럼 보이는 것을 더 광범위하고 국제적으로 수용하는 것과 [맞지 않는] 것은 아니 다.'가 흐름상 적절하므로, 'incompatible'(양립할 수 없는)이 적 절하다. corresponding 상응하는, 일치하는. (C) '어린이 영화가 성인을 위한 더 제대로 된 영화와는 별개의 그리고 완전히 [하위 의] 다른 영역이라는 오래된 편견은 소비의 실상에 의해 뒷받침되 지 않는다'가 흐름상 적절하므로, 'inferior'(하급의, 열등한)'이 적 절하다. superior 우위의, 우월한.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Beethoven’s  drive  to  create  something  <u>new  is  a
reflection  of  his  state  of  curiosity.</u>  Our  brains
experience  a  sense  of  reward  when  we  create
something new in the process of exploring something
uncertain, such as a musical phrase that we’ve never
played or heard before. When our  <u>curiosity leads to
something  novel,  the  resulting  reward  brings  us  a
sense  of  pleasure.</u>  A  number  of  investigators  have
modeled how curiosity influences musical composition.
In the case of Beethoven, computer modeling focused
on  the  thirty- two  piano  sonatas  written  after  age
thirteen revealed that the musical patterns found in all
of Beethoven’s music decreased in later sonatas, while
novel patterns, including patterns that were unique to
a  particular  sonata,  <u>decreased.</u>  In  other  words,
Beethoven’s  music  became  less  <u>predictable  over
time  as  his  curiosity  drove  the  exploration  of  new
musical  ideas.</u>  Curiosity  is  a  powerful  <u>driver  of
human creativity.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Technologists  are  always  on  the  lookout  for
quantifiable metrics.  <u>Measurable inputs to a model
are  their  lifeblood,  and  like  a  social  scientist,  a
technologist  needs  to  identify  concrete  measures,  or
“proxies,”  for  assessing  progress.</u>  This  need  for 
<u>quantifiable proxies produces a bias toward measuring
things that are easy to quantify.</u> But  <u>simple metrics
can take us further away from the important goals we
really  care  about,  which  may  require  complicated
metrics  or  be  extremely  difficult,  or  perhaps
impossible, to reduce to any measure.</u> And when we
have  <u>imperfect or bad proxies, we can easily fall
under the illusion that we are solving for a good end
without  actually  making  genuine  progress  toward  a
worthy  solution.</u>  The  problem  of  proxies  results  in
technologists   frequently   substituting   what   is
measurable for what is  <u>meaningless.</u> As the saying
goes, “Not everything that counts can be counted, and
not everything that can be counted counts.”
* metric: 측정 기준

explanation: 기술자들에게 정량화할 수 있는 프록시에 대한 필요 성은 정량화하기 쉬운 것들을 측정하는 쪽으로 편향을 만들고, 불 완전하거나 잘못된 프록시를 가지고 있을 때, 가치 있는 해결책을 향한 진정한 진전을 실제로 이루지 못하면서 좋은 목적을 위해 문 제를 해결하고 있다는 착각에 쉽게 빠질 수 있으므로 ‘프록시의 문 제는 기술자들이 흔히 의미 있는 것을 측정 가능한 것으로 대체하 는 결과를 낳는다’는 흐름이 적절하다. 따라서 meaningless(의미 없는)을 meaningful(의미있는)등으로 바꿔야 한다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
We  are  the  only  species  that  seasons  its  food,
deliberately  <u>preserving it with the highly flavored
plant parts we call herbs and spices.</u> It’s quite possible
that  our  taste  for  spices  has  an  evolutionary  root.
Many  spices  have  antibacterial  properties  —  in  fact,
common seasonings such as garlic, onion, and oregano
 <u>inhibit the growth of almost every bacterium tested.</u>
And the cultures that make the heaviest use of spices
— think of the garlic and black pepper of Thai food, the
ginger  and  coriander  of  India,  the  chili  peppers  of
Mexico  —  come  from  <u>warmer  climates,  where
bacterial  spoilage  is  a  bigger  issue.</u>  In  contrast,  the
most  <u>lightly spiced cuisines — those of Scandinavia
and northern Europe — are from cooler climates.</u> Our
uniquely human  <u>attention to flavor, in this case the
flavor of spices, turns out to have arisen as a matter of
life and death.</u>

Development  of  the  human  body  from  a  single  cell
provides many examples of the structural richness that
is possible when the  <u>repeated production of random
variation  is  combined  with  nonrandom  selection.</u>  All
phases of body development from embryo to adult 
<u>exhibit random activities at the cellular level, and body
formation depends on the new possibilities generated
by  these  activities  coupled  with  selection  of  those
outcomes  that  satisfy  previously  built- in  criteria.</u>
Always new structure is based on old structure, and at
every  stage  selection  favors  some  cells  and 
<u>unites others.</u> The survivors serve to produce new cells
that undergo further rounds of selection. Except in the
immune system, cells and extensions of cells are not
genetically  selected  during  development,  but  rather,
are  <u>positionally selected.</u> Those in the right place
that make the right connections are stimulated, and
those that don’t are eliminated. This process is much
like sculpting. A natural consequence of the strategy is
great variability from individual to individual at the cell
and  molecular  levels,  even  though  large -scale
structures are quite  <u>similar.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
In  order  to  bring  the  ever-increasing  costs  of  home
care  for  elderly  and  needy  persons  under  control,
managers  of  home  care  providers  have  introduced
management systems. These systems specify tasks of
home care workers and the time and budget available
to  perform  these  tasks.  Electronic  reporting  systems
require home care workers to report on their activities
and the time spent, thus  <u>make the distribution of
time  and  money  visible  and,  in  the  perception  of
managers, controllable.</u> This, in the view of managers,
has  <u>contributed to the resolution of the problem.</u>
The  home  care  workers,  on  the  other  hand,  may
perceive their work not as a set of separate tasks to be
performed as efficiently as possible, but as a service to
be  provided  to  a  client  <u>who  they  may  have
developed  a  relationship  with.</u>  This  includes  having
conversations with clients and  <u>enquiring about the
person’s  well -being.</u>  Restricted  time  and  the
requirement to report may be perceived as obstacles
that make  <u>it impossible to deliver the service that is
needed.</u> If the management systems are too rigid, this
may result in home care workers becoming overloaded
and demotivated.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
It is a common assumption that most vagrant birds are
ultimately doomed, aside from the rare cases where
individuals are able to reorientate and return to their
normal ranges. In turn, it is also commonly assumed
that  vagrancy  itself  is  a  relatively  unimportant
biological phenomenon. This is undoubtedly  <u>true for
the majority of cases, as the most likely outcome of
any given vagrancy event is that the individual will fail
to  find  enough  resources,  and/or  be  exposed  to</u>
<u>inhospitable  environmental  conditions,  and  perish.</u>
However, there are many lines of evidence to suggest
that vagrancy can, on rare occasions, dramatically 
<u>alter  the  fate  of  populations,  species  or  even  whole
ecosystems.</u> Despite being  <u>frequent, these events
can  be  extremely  important  when  viewed  at  the
timescales  over  which  ecological  and  evolutionary
processes unfold.</u> The most profound  <u>consequences
of  vagrancy  relate  to  the  establishment  of  new
breeding  sites,  new  migration  routes  and  wintering
locations.</u>  Each  of  these  can  occur  through  different
mechanisms,  and  at  different  frequencies,  and  they
each have their own unique importance.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Intuition can be great, but it ought to be hard-earned.
Experts, for example, are able to think on their feet
because  they’ve  invested  thousands  of  hours  in
learning  and  practice:  their  intuition  has  become
 <u>data-driven.</u> Only then are they able to act quickly
in accordance with their  <u>internalized expertise and
evidence-based  experience.</u>  Yet  most  people  are  not
experts, though they often think they are. Most of us,
especially when we  <u>interact with others on social
media,  act  with  expert-like  speed  and  conviction,
offering  a  wide  range  of  opinions  on  global  crises,
without the substance of knowledge that supports it.</u>
Thanks  to  AI,  which  ensures  our  messages  are
delivered to an audience more apt to believing it, our
delusions  of  expertise  can  be  <u>collapsed  by  our
personal filter bubble.</u> We have an interesting tendency
to  find  people  more  open-minded,  <u>rational,  and
sensible when they think just like us.</u>

without the substance of knowledge that supports it.</u>

④ <u>collapsed  by  our
personal filter bubble.</u>

far  <u>exceeded our  human  ability  for  understanding
without powerful tools.</u> As a result, data collected in large
data repositories become "data tombs" ─ data archives
that are  <u>hardly visited.</u> Important decisions are often
made based not on the information-rich data stored in
data  repositories  but  rather  on  a  decision  maker's 
<u>instinct,  simply  because  the  decision  maker  does  not
have  the  tools  to  extract  the  valuable  knowledge</u>
<u>hidden in the vast amounts of data.</u> Efforts have been
made  to  develop  expert  system  and  knowledge-based
technologies,  which  typically  rely  on  users  or  domain
experts  to  manually  input  knowledge  into  knowledge
bases. However, this procedure is likely to  <u>prevent
biases  and  errors  and  is  extremely  costly  and  time
consuming.</u>  The  widening  gap  between  data  and
information calls for the systematic development of tools
that  can  turn  data  tombs  into  "golden  nuggets"  of
knowledge.

society.</u>

mainText:
The most prevalent problem kids report is that they feel
like  they  need  to  be  <u>unaccessible at  all  times.</u>
Because   technology   allows   for   it,   they   feel
an  <u>obligation.</u> It's easy for most of us to relate - you
probably feel the same pressure in your own life! It is
really challenging to deal with the fact that we're human
and  can't  always  respond  <u>instantly.</u>  For  a  teen  or
tween  who's  still  learning  the  ins  and  outs  of  social
interactions, it's even  <u>worse.</u> Here's how this behavior
plays out sometimes: Your child texts one of his friends,
and the friend doesn't text back right away. Now it's easy
for your child to think, "This person doesn't want to be
my friend anymore!" So he texts again, and again, and
again  -  "blowing  up  their  phone."  This  can  be  stress-
inducing and even read as  <u>aggressive.</u> But you can
see how easily this could happen.
*tween: (10~12세 사이의) 십대 초반의 아동

drinking  and  various  eating  behaviors  are  the  most
common  health  concerns  targeted  for  behavioral
changes.  Process- addiction  behaviors  (workaholism,

well.   Mental   imagery   combined   with   power
of  suggestion  was  taken  up  as  the  <u>premise  of

technique alone will not produce changes, when used

effective for some people.</u> What mental imagery does
is  <u>reinforce a new desired behavior.</u>  <u>Repeated use
of  images  reinforces  the  desired  behavior  more
strongly over time.</u>

mainText:
Dancers often push themselves to the limits of their
physical capabilities. But that push is misguided if it is
directed toward accomplishing something physically 
<u>impossible.</u> For instance, a tall dancer with  <u>long feet
may wish to perform repetitive vertical jumps to fast
music, pointing his feet while in the air and lowering
his heels to the floor between jumps.</u> That may not be
 <u>possible no matter how strong the dancer is.</u> But a
short-footed  dancer  may  have  no  trouble!  Another
dancer may be  <u>effortless to complete a half-turn in
the air.</u> Understanding the connection between a rapid
turn rate and the alignment of the body close to the
rotation  axis  tells  her  how  to  accomplish  her  turn
successfully. In both of these cases, understanding and
working within the constraints imposed by nature and
described by physical laws  <u>allows dancers to work
efficiently, minimizing potential risk of injury.</u>
*alignment: 정렬 **rotation axis: 회전축

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
We must explore the relationship between children’s 
production  and  consumption  habits.  The  term
“children’s film”  <u>indicates ownership by children –
their cinema – but films supposedly made for children
have always been consumed by audiences of all ages,
particularly  in  commercial  cinemas.</u>  We  can  see  the
considerable  <u>crossover in audience composition for
children’s films with ease.</u> For example, eleven Danish
children’s  and  youth  films  attracted  59  per  cent  of
theatrical admissions in 2007, and German children’s
films  <u>constituted seven out of the top twenty films
at the national box office in 2014.</u> This phenomenon
corresponds   with   a   broader,   international
 <u>acceptance of what is seemingly children’s culture
among  audiences  of  diverse  ages.</u>  The  old  prejudice
that children’s film is some other realm, separate from
(and forever subordinate to) a more legitimate cinema
for  adults  is  <u>confirmed  by  the  realities  of
consumption:  children’s  film  is  at  the  heart  of
contemporary popular culture.</u>
(A), (B), (C)의 각 네모 안에서 문맥에 맞는 낱말로 가장

question: 적절한 것은?
mainText:
Beethoven’s  drive  to  create  something  novel  is  a
reflection  of  his  state  of  curiosity.  Our  brains
experience  a  sense  of  reward  when  we  create
something new in the process of exploring something
(A) [certain / uncertain], such as a musical phrase
that  we’ve  never  played  or  heard  before.  When  our
curiosity  leads  to  something  novel,  the  resulting
reward  brings  us  a  sense  of  pleasure.  A  number  of
investigators  have  modeled  how (B)  [curiosity  /
impatience]  influences  musical  composition.  In  the
case of Beethoven, computer modeling focused on the
thirty- two  piano  sonatas  written  after  age  thirteen
revealed  that  the  musical  patterns  found  in  all  of
Beethoven’s  music  decreased  in  later  sonatas,  while
novel patterns, including patterns that were unique to
a  particular  sonata,  increased.  In  other  words,
Beethoven’s  music  became (C)   [more   /   less]
predictable  over  time  as  his  curiosity  drove  the
exploration  of  new  musical  ideas.  Curiosity  is  a
powerful driver of human creativity.
 <u>certain - impatience - less</u> <u>uncertain - curiosity - more</u> <u>certain - curiosity - more</u> <u>uncertain - impatience - more</u> <u>uncertain - curiosity - less</u>

a  particular  sonata,  increased.  In  other  words,
Beethoven’s  music  became (C)   [more   /   less]
predictable  over  time  as  his  curiosity  drove  the
exploration  of  new  musical  ideas.  Curiosity  is  a
powerful driver of human creativity.
 <u>certain - impatience - less</u> <u>uncertain - curiosity - more</u> <u>certain - curiosity - more</u> <u>uncertain - impatience - more</u> <u>uncertain - curiosity - less</u>
options: ① <u>certain - impatience - less</u>
② <u>uncertain - curiosity - more</u>
③ <u>certain - curiosity - more</u>
④ <u>uncertain - impatience - more</u>
⑤ <u>uncertain - curiosity - less</u>
explanation: (A) '[확실하지 않은] 것을 탐구하는 과정에서 새로 운 것을 발견하는 것'이 문맥상 알맞으므로, 'uncertain'이 적절하 다. (B) '어떻게 [호기심]이 음악작곡에 영향을 끼치는지 모델링했 다'는 것이 문맥상 알맞으므로, 'curiosity'이 적절하다. (C) '베토 벤의 음악 스타일은 시간이 지날 수록 [덜] 예측가능해졌다'는 것 이 문맥상 알맞으므로, 'less'가 적절하다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Technologists  are  always  on  the  lookout  for
quantifiable metrics. Measurable inputs to a model are
their lifeblood, and like a social scientist, a technologist
needs to identify  <u>concrete measures, or “proxies,”
for  assessing  progress.</u>  This  need  for  quantifiable
proxies produces a bias toward measuring things that
are  <u>difficult to quantify.</u> But simple metrics can take
us further away from the  <u>important goals we really
care about, which may require complicated metrics or
be extremely difficult, or perhaps impossible, to reduce
to any measure.</u> And when we have imperfect or bad
proxies, we can easily fall under the illusion that we
are  solving  for  a  good  end  without  actually  making
genuine  progress  toward  a  <u>worthy  solution.</u>  The
problem   of   proxies   results   in   technologists
frequently substituting what is  <u>measurable for what
is meaningful.</u> As the saying goes, “Not everything that
counts can be counted, and not everything that can be
counted counts.”

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
In  order  to  bring  the  ever-increasing  costs  of  home
care  for  elderly  and  needy  persons  under  control,
managers  of  home  care  providers  have  introduced
management systems. These systems  <u>clarify tasks
of  home  care  workers  and  the  time  and  budget
available to perform these tasks.</u> Electronic reporting
systems require home care workers to report on their
activities  and  the  time  spent,  thus  making  the
distribution  of  time  and  money  visible  and,  in  the
perception  of  managers,  <u>noticeable.</u>  This,  in  the
view of managers, has  <u>contributed to the resolution
of the problem.</u> The home care workers, on the other
hand, may perceive their work not as a set of separate
tasks to be performed as efficiently as possible, but as
a  <u>service to be provided to a client with whom they
may  have  developed  a  relationship.</u>  This  includes
having conversations with clients and enquiring about
the  person’s  well -being.  Restricted  time  and  the
requirement to report may be perceived as obstacles
that make it impossible to deliver the service that is
needed. Unless the management systems are  <u>rigid,
this  may  result  in  home  care  workers  becoming
overloaded and demotivated.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
It is a common assumption that most vagrant birds are
ultimately doomed, aside from the rare cases where
individuals are able to reorientate and return to their
normal ranges. In turn, it is also commonly assumed
that  vagrancy  itself  is  a  relatively  <u>unimportant
biological  phenomenon.</u>  This  is  undoubtedly  true  for
the majority of cases, as the most  <u>unlikely outcome
of any given vagrancy event is that the individual will
fail to find enough resources, and/or be exposed to</u>
<u>inhospitable  environmental  conditions,  and  perish.</u>
However, there are many lines of evidence to suggest
that  vagrancy  can,  on  rare  occasions,  dramatically
alter  the  fate  of  populations,  species  or  even  whole
ecosystems. Despite being  <u>infrequent, these events
can  be  extremely  important  when  viewed  at  the
timescales  over  which  ecological  and  evolutionary
processes</u> <u>unfold.</u> The most profound consequences
of  vagrancy  relate  to  the  establishment  of  new
breeding  sites,  new  migration  routes  and  wintering
locations.  Each  of  these  can  occur  through  different
mechanisms,  and  at  different  frequencies,  and  they
each have their own unique importance.

mainText:
Intuition can be great, but it ought to be hard-earned.
Experts, for example, are able to think on their feet
because  they’ve  invested  thousands  of  hours  in
learning  and  practice:  their  intuition  has  become 
<u>data-driven.</u> Only then are they able to act quickly in
accordance  with  their  <u>ingrained  expertise  and
evidence- based  experience.</u>  Yet  most  people  are  not
experts, though they often think they are. Most of us,
especially  when  we  interact  with  others  on  social
media, act with expert-like speed and  <u>conviction,
offering  a  wide  range  of  opinions  on  global  crises,
without the substance of knowledge that</u> <u>sustain it.</u>
And thanks to AI, which ensures that our messages
are delivered to an audience more inclined to believing
it, our  <u>skepticism of expertise can be reinforced by
our  personal  filter  bubble.</u>  We  have  an  interesting
tendency to find people more open-minded, rational,
and sensible when they think just like us.

The  fast -growing,  tremendous  amount  of  data,
collected  and  stored  in  large  and  numerous  data
repositories, has  <u>far exceeded our human ability for
understanding without powerful tools.</u> As a result, data
collected  in  large  data  repositories  become  “data
tombs”  —  data  archives  that  are  hardly  visited.
Important decisions are  <u>often made based not on
the  information–rich  data  stored  in  data  repositories
but  rather  on  a  decision  maker’s  instinct,  simply
because the decision maker does not have the tools to
extract the</u> <u>valuable knowledge hidden in the vast
amounts of data.</u> Efforts have been made to develop
expert  system  and  knowledge-based  technologies,
which typically  <u>rely on users or domain experts to
manually  input  knowledge  into  knowledge  bases.</u>
However, this procedure is likely to cause biases and
errors and is extremely costly and time  <u>saving.</u> The
widening gap between data and information calls for
the systematic development of tools that can turn data
tombs into “golden nuggets” of knowledge.

mainText:
Too  many  times  people,  especially  in  today’s
generation, expect things to just happen  <u>right away.</u>
When we have these  <u>false expectations, it tends to
forbid us to continue to move forward.</u> Because this is
a  high  tech  society,  everything  we  want  has  to  be
within the parameters of our comfort and convenience.
If it doesn’t happen fast enough, we’re tempted to 
<u>lose interest.</u> So many people don’t want to take the
time  it  requires  to  be  successful.  Success  is  not  a
matter of mere  <u>efforts; you should develop patience
in  order  to  achieve  it.</u>  Have  you  fallen  prey  to 
<u>impatience?</u> Great things take time to build.

We tend to  <u>overrate the impact of new technologies
in  part  because  older  technologies  have  become
absorbed into the furniture of our lives, so as to be
almost invisible.</u> Take the baby bottle. Here is a simple
implement  that  has  transformed  a  <u>fundamental
human  experience  for  vast  numbers  of  infants  and
mothers,  yet  it  finds  no  place  in  our  histories  of
technology.</u> This technology might be thought of as a
classic  <u>time-shifting  device, as it enables mothers
to exercise more control over the timing of feeding.</u> It
can also function to  <u>exhaust time, as bottle feeding
allows for someone else to substitute for the mother’s
time.</u> Potentially, therefore, it has  <u>huge implications
for the management of time in everyday life, yet it is
entirely  overlooked  in  discussions  of  high-speed
society.</u>

The most prevalent problem kids report is that they
feel  like  they  need  to  be  accessible  at  all  times.
Because  technology  allows  for  it,  they  feel  an 
<u>obligation.</u>  It’s  easy  for  most  of  us  to  relate  —  you
probably feel the same pressure in your own life! It is
really  <u>difficult to deal with the fact that we’re human
and can’t always respond instantly.</u> For a teen or tween
who’s  still  learning  the  ins  and  outs  of  social
interactions,  it’s  even  <u>better.</u>  Here’s  how  this
behavior plays out sometimes: Your child texts one of
his friends, and the friend doesn’t text back right away.
Now  it’s  easy  for  your  child  to  think,  “This  person
doesn’t want to be my friend anymore!” So he texts
again,  and  again,  and  again  —  “blowing  up  their
phone.” This can be stress- inducing and even read as
 <u>aggressive.</u> But you can see how  <u>easily this could
happen.</u>

again,  and  again,  and  again  —  “blowing  up  their
phone.” This can be stress- inducing and even read as
 <u>aggressive.</u> But you can see how  <u>easily this could
happen.</u>
options: ① <u>obligation.</u>

② <u>difficult to deal with the fact that we’re human
and can’t always respond instantly.</u>
③ <u>better.</u>
④ <u>aggressive.</u>

⑤ <u>easily this could
happen.</u>
explanation: 아이들은 그들이 항상 연락될 수 있어야 한다고 느 끼는데, 예를 들어, 여러분의 자녀가 친구 중 한 명에게 문자 메시 지를 보내고, 그 친구가 즉시 답장을 보내지 않는다면, 이제 여러 분의 자녀는 “얘는 더 이상 내 친구가 되기를 원하지 않는구나!”라 고 생각하기 쉽다고 했으므로, 십대나 십대 초반의 아동에게 상황 은 훨씬 더 심각하다. 따라서 ③ better를 worse 등으로 고쳐야 한다. [변형] ② difficult : challenging 응용

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
For  years,  many  psychologists  have  held  strongly  to
the belief that the key to addressing negative health
habits is to change behavior. This, more than values
and  attitudes,  is  the  part  of  personality  that  is
 <u>easiest to change.</u> Ingestive habits such as smoking,
drinking  and  various  eating  behaviors  are  the  most
common  health  concerns  <u>targeted  for  behavioral
changes.</u>  Process -addiction  behaviors  (workaholism,
shopaholism,  and  the  like)  fall  into  this  category  as
well.   Mental   imagery   combined   with   power
of  suggestion  was  taken  up  as  the  premise  of
behavioral    medicine    to help    people
change  <u>negative health behaviors into positive ones.</u>
Although  this  technique  alone  will  not  produce
changes,    when    used    alongside    other
behavior  modification  tactics  and  coping  strategies,
behavioral changes have proved  <u>ineffective for some
people.</u> What mental imagery does is  <u>reinforce a
new  desired  behavior.</u>  Repeated  use  of  images
reinforces  the  desired  behavior  more strongly  over
time.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하지 않은 것은?
mainText:
Dancers often push themselves to the limits of their
physical capabilities. But that push is misguided if it is
directed toward accomplishing something physically 
<u>achievable.</u> For instance, a tall dancer with long feet
may wish to perform repetitive vertical jumps to fast
music, pointing his feet while in the air and lowering
his  heels  to  the  floor  between  jumps.  That  may  be
impossible no matter how strong the dancer is. But a
short-footed  dancer  may  find  the  movement  <u>less
challenging!</u>  Another  dancer  may  be  struggling  to
complete  a  half-turn  in  the  air.  Understanding  the
connection  between  a  rapid  turn  rate  and  the
alignment of the body close to the rotation axis tells
her how to accomplish her turn  <u>effectively.</u> In both
of  these  cases,  recognizing  and  adapting  to  the 
<u>restrictions  determined  by  nature  and  described  by
physical laws allows dancers to work efficiently.</u> This
understanding   also   helps   minimize   their 
<u>susceptibility to injury.</u>

explanation: 그렇게 묀어붙이는 것이 물리적으로 불가능한 것을 달성하는 쪽으로 향하게 된다면 그것은 잘못 이해한 것이라는 말 이 문맥상 자연스러우므로, ①의 achievable (달성할 수 있는)을 impossible (불가능한) 등으로 고쳐야 한다. (본문변형)

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 문맥상 낱말의 쓰임이 적절하 지 않은 것은?
mainText:
We  must  explore  the  relationship  between  children’s
film production and  <u>consumption habits.</u> The term
“children’s film” implies ownership by children — their
cinema — but films supposedly made for children have
always  been  consumed  by  audiences  of  all  ages,
particularly  in  commercial  cinemas.  The  considerable
 <u>crossover  in  audience  composition  for  children’s
films can be shown by the fact that, in 2007, eleven
Danish children’s and youth films attracted 59 percent
of  theatrical  admissions,  and  in  2014,  German
children’s  films</u> <u>comprised  seven  out  of  the  top
twenty  films  at  the  national  box  office.</u>  This
phenomenon corresponds with a broader, international
 <u>embrace  of  what  is  seemingly  children’s  culture
among  audiences  of  diverse  ages.</u>  The  old  prejudice
that children’s film is some other realm, separate from
(and forever subordinate to) a more legitimate cinema
for  adults  is  <u>supported  by  the  realities  of
consumption:  children’s  film  is  at  the  heart  of
contemporary popular culture.</u>
